Award.AbstractNarration:
DePaul University, in partnership with Loyola University Chicago, the University of Illinois Chicago and the Chicago Public School District (CPS), proposes a project -- Accelerate ECS4ALL -- that will create a robust peer-coaching model to support the growing number of novice Exploring Computer Science (ECS) teachers in Chicago and across the country. Over the last few years, under the Taste of Computing project and CPS' CS4All initiative, over 100 teachers have participated in the ECS Professional Development, over 60% of CPS high schools are now offering the ECS curriculum, and approximately 7,000 students are taking the course each year. Of these students, 43% are female, 41% African American, and 43% Hispanic, significantly increasing exposure to CS among traditionally underrepresented populations. Peer coaching is needed now to sustain these successes, ensuring that novice teachers are able to fully embrace the guided-inquiry, equitable pedagogical approach of ECS and live it in their classrooms.

A Coach in Development Program will be developed and 15-20 experienced ECS teachers will participate in the program before being deployed as peer coaches in CPS high schools. They will, for example, observe classrooms through visits and video recordings, and work with teachers on reflecting, planning, goal-framing, and analysis of student work. The project will also support recruiting efforts targeted at teachers and administrators to facilitate 100% enrollment of CPS schools in CS4ALL.

ProgramReference.Text: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

POR.DRECONTENT:
As part of the effort to engage all students with a high-quality computer science experience, the Office of Computer Science in Chicago Public Schools, in collaboration with the Chicago Alliance for Equity in Computer Science (CAFÉCS), spent the past several years developing and refining approaches to supplement the professional development of novice Exploring Computer Science (ECS) teachers. One of the primary means for accomplishing this is through the development of an integrated, scalable coaching model targeted at novice ECS teachers. 

 

The ECS coaching model has been successful in reaching increasing numbers of ECS teachers at a growing number of high schools each year. Even with a two-week teachers’ strike in the fall and the disruption of the COVID-19 pandemic in the spring, the coaches increased the number of interactions with teachers during the 2019-2020 school year over the previous year by 32%. In the 2019-2020 school year, 54 ECS teachers received coaching across 34 different high schools. Coaching interactions varied by type. Almost a quarter were planning sessions (23%), and a significant portion were classroom visits (17%), relationship-building meetings (6%), or post-visit debriefs (10%).

 

Teachers who participated in the coaching were very positive about their experiences. Content knowledge, student engagement, and classroom culture have remained a consistent set of needs for ECS teachers. These topics were frequently the areas of focus of the coaching interactions (the two most common areas of focus for the coaching interactions were student engagement and computer science content). Computer science content knowledge, in particular, was an area of need identified by many of the participating teachers and this was an area where teachers reported that coaching was particularly beneficial.

 

The coaching model evolved over the four years of implementation, with some of the changes coming directly from feedback from teacher participants.

  • The coaching model evolved from several part-time coaches to two full-time coaches. Part-time coaching was difficult to implement because of logistical challenges that halted momentum between the coach and teacher. The shift to full-time coaches removed these barriers.

  • In part due to a change in the professional development for coaches, the coaching model shifted to a focus on student learning goals rather than teacher lesson goals.

  • At the start of the project, the coaching protocol included a pre-visit planning call, the visit, a post-visit debrief, and documentation. The protocol was expanded to include goal setting, videorecording lessons, modeling lessons, collecting and analyzing real time student classroom data, peer teaching visits to other schools, school team meetings, relationship-building meetings with teachers, classroom culture and climate visits, and learning walks, 

  • In response to teacher feedback and the shift to remote teaching, the coaching team developed several online resources for teachers, including a Coaching Café, which is an informal online space for coaches and teachers to discuss pedagogical topics, and a Teachers’ Lounge, which provides opportunities for small groups of ECS teachers to collaborate with the coaches on best practices and teaching strategies regarding specific ECS lessons.


Coaching Theory of Change. As an outcome of the project, the Accelerate ECS4All coaches, in collaboration with researchers from The Learning Partnership and the CAFÉCS leadership team, also developed a coaching theory of change which lays out the ongoing research agenda for coaching in CPS. The theory of change outlines the current state of coaching for ECS, identifies key barriers and assets, lists strategies and tactics being used to further strengthen the coaching model, lists anticipated progress milestones, and the desired ends of the project. The coaches began to collect data that addressed progress milestones prior to the pandemic, including student self-reported data on their engagement in the classroom and the extent to which their teacher respects different perspectives and promotes discussion. The desired ends of the project range from creating a robust, dynamic coaching model to mentoring new coaches and increasing the retention of ECS teachers. The theory of change frames CPS’ continuous improvement efforts for ECS instructional coaching.
